Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q:  A 61-year-old man was started on rosuvastatin 40 mg 8 weeks ago and presents today for a follow-up. He complains of pain in his legs and general weakness. On physical exam, he has full range of motion of his extremities but complains of pain. His blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg and heart rate is 74/min. The decision is made to stop the statin and return to the clinic in 2 weeks to assess any changes in symptoms. After stopping the statin, his muscular symptoms resolve. What is the next best course of action to take regarding his LDL control?
(A) Restart rosuvastatin at a lower dose (B) Initiate fenofibrate (C) Initiate a different statin (D) Initiate fish oils
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q:  A 61-year-old man was started on rosuvastatin 40 mg 8 weeks ago and presents today for a follow-up. He complains of pain in his legs and general weakness. On physical exam, he has full range of motion of his extremities but complains of pain. His blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg and heart rate is 74/min. The decision is made to stop the statin and return to the clinic in 2 weeks to assess any changes in symptoms. After stopping the statin, his muscular symptoms resolve. What is the next best course of action to take regarding his LDL control?
options: (A) Restart rosuvastatin at a lower dose (B) Initiate fenofibrate (C) Initiate a different statin (D) Initiate fish oils
outputs:
The patient was started on rosuvastatin 40 mg 8 weeks ago and presents with pain in his legs and general weakness. The decision is made to stop the statin and return to the clinic in 2 weeks to assess any changes in symptoms. After stopping the statin, his muscular symptoms resolve. The patient's LDL control is important, but the statin is not tolerated well. The next best course of action would be to restart rosuvastatin at a lower dose. This will allow the patient to continue to receive the benefits of LDL lowering while minimizing the risk of muscle pain. The answer is (A).

Q: A 40-year-old woman with a history of migraines and a family history of breast cancer presents for a routine check-up. She is currently taking a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) for breast cancer prevention. She has been compliant with her medication regimen and has not noticed any adverse effects. Her blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 68/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On physical examination, there are no abnormalities. A mammogram performed 6 months ago showed no evidence of breast cancer. She has a strong family history of breast cancer in a first-degree relative. The patient is concerned about the risk of endometrial cancer associated with her medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an endometrial biopsy (B) Order a transvaginal ultrasound (C) Order a CA-125 (D) Reassure the patient and continue her current medication regimen.
A: Let's think step by step. The patient is taking a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) for breast cancer prevention. She has a strong family history of breast cancer in a first-degree relative. She is concerned about the risk of endometrial cancer associated with her medication. The patient's current medication regimen is appropriate for breast cancer prevention, but the risk of endometrial cancer should also be considered. The most appropriate next step in management would be to order a transvaginal ultrasound to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. This will allow the patient to continue to receive the benefits of breast cancer prevention while minimizing the risk of endometrial cancer. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She has a history of hypertension and migraines. She has been taking a calcium channel blocker and a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for her headaches. She is afebrile and her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. She is able to speak in short, fragmented sentences and has difficulty articulating words. She has left-sided weakness and cannot lift her left arm or leg. The patient's speech and motor deficits are consistent with a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarction. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) (B) Administer intravenous heparin (C) Perform a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain with and without contrast (D) Administer aspirin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and migraines. She is taking a calcium channel blocker and a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for her headaches. She presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. Her speech and motor deficits are consistent with a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarction. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) to dissolve the clot causing the infarction. This will minimize the damage to the brain and improve the patient's chances of recovery. The answer is (A).

Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: An unidentified surgical specimen is received for histopathologic analysis. A portion of the specimen is cut and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The remainder is analyzed and is found to contains type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate. Which of the following structures is most likely the origin of this surgical specimen?
(A) Blood vessel (B) Pinna (C) Lens (D) Larynx
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: An unidentified surgical specimen is received for histopathologic analysis. A portion of the specimen is cut and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. The remainder is analyzed and is found to contains type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate. Which of the following structures is most likely the origin of this surgical specimen?
options: (A) Blood vessel (B) Pinna (C) Lens (D) Larynx
outputs:
The specimen contains type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate, which are found in cartilage. The specimen is unlikely to be from a blood vessel, pinna, or lens because these structures do not contain cartilage. Therefore, the most likely origin of the surgical specimen is the larynx, which contains cartilage in the form of the cricoid and arytenoid cartilages. The answer is (D).

Q: A 75-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of progressive weakness and fatigue. She has also experienced a 10-pound weight loss over the past 3 months. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis. Her medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, and alendronate. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 18/min. There is no evidence of jugular venous distension. Her liver and spleen are not enlarged. There is no lymphadenopathy. The patient's serum creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL, and her estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is 45 mL/min/1.73 m2. Urinalysis shows 1+ protein and numerous hyaline casts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Start darbepoetin alfa (B) Obtain a renal ultrasound (C) Perform a kidney biopsy (D) Start atorvastatin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis. She has progressive weakness and fatigue and has lost 10 pounds over the past 3 months. Her serum creatinine level is elevated at 1.8 mg/dL, and her estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is decreased at 45 mL/min/1.73 m2. Urinalysis shows 1+ protein and numerous hyaline casts. These findings are consistent with chronic kidney disease (CKD). The patient's history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia increases her risk of developing CKD. The patient's kidney function is decreased, and she has proteinuria, which is consistent with CKD. The most appropriate next step in management is to start darbepoetin alfa, a medication that stimulates the production of red blood cells, to treat the patient's anemia. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-month history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of knee trauma or previous knee surgery. She has no swelling or erythema over the knee. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation over the medial tibial condyle. There is no effusion or warmth. The patient's knee is stable, and there is no ligamentous laxity. The patient has full range of motion, and there is no pain with flexion or extension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an MRI of the knee (B) Administer intra-articular corticosteroids (C) Order a radionuclide bone scan (D) Prescribe physical therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has worsening left knee pain for 1 month, without any history of knee trauma or surgery. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the medial tibial condyle. The patient has full range of motion and no pain with flexion or extension. There is no swelling, erythema, effusion, warmth, or ligamentous laxity. The patient has no history of previous knee problems. The most likely diagnosis is patellofemoral pain syndrome. The next step in management would be to prescribe physical therapy to improve the strength and flexibility of the quadriceps and

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a small bowel perforation. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single perforation in the terminal ileum is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
(A) Increase the FiO2 (B) Increase the tidal volume (C) Increase PEEP (D) Increase the respiratory rate
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a small bowel perforation. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single perforation in the terminal ileum is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
options: (A) Increase the FiO2 (B) Increase the tidal volume (C) Increase PEEP (D) Increase the respiratory rate
outputs: The patient has undergone surgery for a small bowel perforation. She is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Her vital signs are stable, and her arterial blood gas analysis shows pH 7.44, pO2 54 mm Hg, pCO2 31 mm Hg, and HCO3- 22 mm Hg. These values indicate that the patient has respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation. The patient's respiratory rate is 12/min, which is low. The tidal volume is 1000 mL, which is appropriate. The positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is 2.5 cm H2O, which is also appropriate. The FiO2 is 50%, which is appropriate. The patient's lung examination shows bilateral rales, which indicates that the patient has pulmonary congestion. The patient's abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions, which indicates that the patient's bowel obstruction has not resolved. The patient's arterial blood gas analysis indicates that the patient has metabolic acidosis due to hypoventilation. The patient's low respiratory rate and bilateral rales suggest that the patient is not receiving enough oxygen. The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient would be to increase the respiratory rate to 18–20/min to improve oxygenation and to monitor the patient's blood gas levels closely. The answer is (D).

Q: A 43-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C and current intravenous drug use presents with 5 days of fever, chills, headache, and severe back pain. On physical exam, temperature is 100.6 deg F (38.1 deg C), blood pressure is 109/56 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is thin and diaphoretic with pinpoint pupils, poor dentition, and track marks on his arms and legs. A high-pitched systolic murmur is heard, loudest in the left sternal border and with inspiration. He is admitted to the hospital and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. One of the blood cultures drawn 12 hours ago returns positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
(A) Repeat blood cultures now (B) Repeat blood cultures 24 hours after initial cultures were drawn (C) Repeat blood cultures 48 hours after initial cultures were drawn (D) Do not repeat blood cultures
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 43-year-old man with a history of hepatitis C and current intravenous drug use presents with 5 days of fever, chills, headache, and severe back pain. On physical exam, temperature is 100.6 deg F (38.1 deg C), blood pressure is 109/56 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is thin and diaphoretic with pinpoint pupils, poor dentition, and track marks on his arms and legs. A high-pitched systolic murmur is heard, loudest in the left sternal border and with inspiration. He is admitted to the hospital and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. One of the blood cultures drawn 12 hours ago returns positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
options: (A) Repeat blood cultures now (B) Repeat blood cultures 24 hours after initial cultures were drawn (C) Repeat blood cultures 48 hours after initial cultures were drawn (D) Do not repeat blood cultures
outputs:
The patient has a history of hepatitis C and current intravenous drug use. He presents with fever, chills, headache, and severe back pain. On physical exam, he is thin and diaphoretic with pinpoint pupils, poor dentition, and track marks on his arms and legs. A high-pitched systolic murmur is heard, loudest in the left sternal border and with inspiration. He is admitted to the hospital and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. One of the blood cultures drawn 12 hours ago returns positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient has signs of endocarditis. The patient's blood cultures drawn 12 hours ago returned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. To confirm the diagnosis of endocarditis, repeat blood cultures should be drawn now. The answer is (A).

Q: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-year history of progressive weakness in his legs and difficulty with walking. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes atorvastatin and lisinopril. He has no family history of neurological disease. On physical exam, he has decreased muscle strength in his lower extremities, atrophy of his calf muscles, and decreased reflexes. His sensation is preserved. There is no evidence of sensory level or Horner's syndrome. A lumbar puncture shows a protein of 48 mg/dL and a white blood cell count of 10/mm3. An MRI of the spinal cord shows a lengthwise lesion from C4 to C7. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

On physical exam, he has decreased muscle strength in his lower extremities, atrophy of his calf muscles, and decreased reflexes. His sensation is preserved. There is no evidence of sensory level or Horner's syndrome. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with lower motor neuron syndrome. The MRI of the spinal cord shows a lengthwise lesion from C4 to C7. This is consistent with a diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy. The answer is (D).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. (A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. Prior treatment

Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit

Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 42-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician for intermittent fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has not seen a doctor since he became uninsured 2 years ago. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm3 (N ≥ 500 mm3). Blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms. A PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
(A) Voriconazole (B) Amphotericin B and itraconazole (C) Erythromycin (D) Azithromycin and ethambutol

question: Q: A 42-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician for intermittent fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has not seen a doctor since he became uninsured 2 years ago. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm3 (N ≥ 500 mm3). Blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms. A PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
options: (A) Voriconazole (B) Amphotericin B and itraconazole (C) Erythromycin (D) Azithromycin and ethambutol
outputs:
The patient has AIDS and presents with fever, nonproductive cough, malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and weight loss. He has not seen a doctor since he became uninsured 2 years ago. The patient's CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 49/mm3, which is below the normal range (≥500 mm3). Blood cultures grow acid-fast organisms. The patient has tuberculosis. The PPD skin test shows 4 mm of induration, which is consistent with a positive reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The patient's symptoms and low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count suggest that he has disseminated tuberculosis. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition is a combination of antituberculous medications. The answer is (B).

Q: A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of sudden onset, severe, substernal pain. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. She has been treated for hypertension with lisinopril for the past 5 years. She has no history of chest pain or shortness of breath. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform an electrocardiogram (B) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (C) Administer intravenous furosemide (D) Perform a chest x-ray
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-hour history of sudden onset, severe, substernal pain. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. She has been treated for hypertension with lisinopril for the past 5 years. She has no history of chest pain or shortness of breath. The patient's symptoms could be consistent with a myocardial infarction. However, the absence of any cardiovascular risk factors and the lack of any electrocardiographic changes suggest that this is unlikely. The patient's history of hypertension and substernal pain suggests that the pain may be related to esophageal spasm. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform an electrocardiogram to rule out myocardial infarction. The answer is (A).

Q: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening pain in the right shoulder and arm. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is currently taking lisinopril and simvastatin. She appears comfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a positive Adson's sign and a positive Jawetz-Lewandowski sign. The patient has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform MRI of the right shoulder (B) Perform MRI of the cervical spine (C) Perform electromyography and nerve conduction studies (D) Administer intravenous methylprednisolone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 6-month history of worsening pain in the right shoulder and arm. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is currently taking lisinopril and simvastatin. She appears comfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a positive Adson's sign and a positive Jawetz-Lewandowski sign. The patient has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a neurogenic disorder. The patient's history of smoking suggests that she may have a neurogenic disorder related to emphysema. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform electromyography and nerve conduction studies to determine the extent of nerve damage. The answer is (C).

Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
(A) JAK2 tyrosine kinase (B) E2F transcription factors (C) Phosphoprotein p53 (D) Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
options: (A) JAK2 tyrosine kinase (B) E2F transcription factors (C) Phosphoprotein p53 (D) Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors
outputs:
The patient had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy showed an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area showed carcinoma-in-situ. Carcinoma-in-situ is caused by the abnormal growth and division of squamous cells on the surface of the cervix. The abnormal growth and division of squamous cells on the surface of the cervix is caused by the activation of E2F transcription factors. The E2F transcription factors are activated by the binding of growth factors to their receptors on the surface of squamous cells. The binding of growth factors to their receptors on the surface of squamous cells is the best explanation for the pathogenesis of this condition. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fever, headache, and neck stiffness. He also has had a sore throat and difficulty swallowing for the past week. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension. He appears acutely ill. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a temperature of 39.1°C (102.4°F), a pulse of 110/min, and a respiratory rate of 18/min. There is a mild neck stiffness. The oropharynx is erythematous, and there are several small ulcers on the soft palate and uvula. A rapid strep test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous penicillin (B) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (C) Administer oral amoxicillin (D) Administer oral ciprofloxacin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a fever, headache, neck stiffness, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension. He appears acutely ill. The rapid strep test is positive. The patient has acute strep pharyngitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous penicillin. Penicillin is the drug of choice for strep pharyngitis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss, dizziness, and nausea. She has a history of hypertension and has been taking hydrochlorothiazide for the past year. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows Weber Class III/IV hearing loss. The patient is unable to stand because of dizziness. The patient is nauseous but has not vomited. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss, dizziness, and nausea. She has a history of hypertension and has been taking hydrochlorothiazide for the past year. She appears uncomfortable. The patient has a Weber Class III/IV hearing loss. The patient is unable to stand because of dizziness. The patient is nauseous but has not vomited. There are no abnormalities on the neurological examination. The patient has Meniere's disease. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous metoclopramide. Metoclopramide is used to treat nausea and vomiting associated with Meniere's disease. The answer is (B).

She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?
(A) PPV decreases, NPV decreases (B) PPV decreases, NPV increases (C) PPV increases, NPV decreases (D) PPV unchanged, NPV unchanged
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A research group has developed a low-cost diagnostic retinal imaging device for cytomegalovirus retinitis in a population of HIV-infected patients. In a pilot study of 50 patients, the imaging test detected the presence of CMV retinitis in 50% of the patients. An ophthalmologist slit lamp examination, which was performed for each patient to serve as the gold standard for diagnosis, confirmed a diagnosis of CMV retinitis in 20 patients that were found to be positive through imaging, as well as 1 patient who tested negative with the device. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy, how will positive predictive value and negative predictive value of the diagnostic test be affected?
options: (A) PPV decreases, NPV decreases (B) PPV decreases, NPV increases (C) PPV increases, NPV decreases (D) PPV unchanged, NPV unchanged
outputs:
The prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases due to increased access to antiretroviral therapy. The prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population is the proportion of people with CMV retinitis in the population. If the prevalence of CMV retinitis in the population decreases, the number of true positive cases detected by the diagnostic test will also decrease. The number of false positive cases will remain the same. As a result, the positive predictive value (PPV) of the diagnostic test will decrease. The negative predictive value (NPV) of the diagnostic test will increase. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss and severe vertigo that started 2 hours ago. She has no history of hearing loss or vertigo. She denies recent infections, head trauma, or recent medication use. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a Weber Class III/IV hearing loss and a positive head thrust test. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous steroids (B) Administer intravenous antibiotics (C) Order an MRI of the internal auditory meatus (D) Order a CT scan of the temporal bone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss and severe vertigo. The patient has no history of hearing loss or vertigo. She denies recent infections, head trauma, or recent medication use. Physical examination shows a Weber Class III/IV hearing loss and a positive head thrust test. The patient has no other symptoms. Sudden hearing loss and severe vertigo are consistent with Meniere's disease. Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can cause vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the affected ear. Meniere's disease typically affects one ear. The most appropriate next step in management is to order an MRI of the internal auditory meatus. The MRI will help to rule out other causes of sudden hearing loss and vertigo, such as a tumor or inflammation. The answer is (C).

Q: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe left knee pain that started 2 hours ago. He has no history of knee problems. He denies recent trauma or injuries. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and moderate pain to palpation over the left knee. There is no erythema or warmth. The patient can bear weight but is limping. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an MRI of the knee (B) Order an arthrocentesis (C) Administer intravenous antibiotics (D) Administer intravenous analgesia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden onset of severe left knee pain. The patient has no history of knee problems. He denies recent trauma or injuries. Physical examination shows swelling and moderate pain to palpation over the left knee. There is no erythema or warmth. The patient can bear weight but is limping. The patient may have a meniscal tear or ligamentous injury. The most appropriate next step in management is to order an MRI of the knee. The MRI will help to diagnose the cause of the patient's knee pain. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old woman is brought into the clinic by a concerned neighbor who says that the patient is often seen setting up bear traps all around her property because of an impending ‘invasion of the mole people.’ The patient has come to the clinic wearing a garlic necklace. She vaguely explains that the necklace is to mask her scent from the moles tracking her. She has no past psychiatric history and she denies hearing voices or seeing objects. No significant past medical history. Although she has lived in the same community for years, she says she usually keeps to herself and does not have many friends. She holds a regular job at the local hardware store and lives alone. Which of the following is the best initial course of treatment for this patient?
(A) Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) (B) The patient does not require any intervention (C) Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (D) Refer to outpatient group therapy
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 35-year-old woman is brought into the clinic by a concerned neighbor who says that the patient is often seen setting up bear traps all around her property because of an impending ‘invasion of the mole people.’ The patient has come to the clinic wearing a garlic necklace. She vaguely explains that the necklace is to mask her scent from the moles tracking her. She has no past psychiatric history and she denies hearing voices or seeing objects. No significant past medical history. Although she has lived in the same community for years, she says she usually keeps to herself and does not have many friends. She holds a regular job at the local hardware store and lives alone. Which of the following is the best initial course of treatment for this patient?
options: (A) Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) (B) The patient does not require any intervention (C) Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (D) Refer to outpatient group therapy
outputs:
The patient is brought to the clinic by a concerned neighbor who says that the patient is setting up bear traps around her property because of an impending invasion of the mole people. The patient is wearing a garlic necklace to mask her scent from the moles tracking her. The patient has no past psychiatric history and denies hearing voices or seeing objects. The patient has a regular job at the local hardware store and lives alone. The patient's behavior is consistent with delusional disorder. Delusional disorder is a mental health condition characterized by one or more non-bizarre delusions that last for at least one month. The patient's delusion about the mole people invasion is a non-bizarre delusion because it could potentially happen in reality, although it is highly unlikely. The best initial course of treatment for this patient would be cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of psychotherapy that helps people identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors. It is effective in treating delusional disorder and can help the patient identify and challenge their delusional beliefs. The answer is (A).

Q: A 30-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches and major depressive disorder presents to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has no history of substance abuse or significant medical or surgical history. She takes no medications regularly. She is currently taking a week-long course of amoxicillin for a urinary tract infection. Vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse 110/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count shows WBC 12,000/mm3, hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL, hematocrit 39%, platelet count 240,000/mm3. Electrolyte panel shows Na 138 mEq/L, K 4.2 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L, and CO2 24 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood, 1+ protein, and numerous WBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute severe migraine (B) Acute mountain sickness (C) Acute stroke (D) Acute kidney injury
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of migraine headaches and major depressive disorder. She presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has no history of substance abuse or significant medical or surgical history. She takes no medications regularly. She is currently taking a week-long course of amoxicillin for a urinary tract infection. The patient's symptoms are consistent with acute severe migraine. The patient's history of migraine headaches and the sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting support this diagnosis. The patient's normal vital signs and complete blood count also support this diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 71-year-old man complains of urinary hesitancy and nocturia of increasing frequency over the past several months. Digital rectal exam was positive for a slightly enlarged prostate but did not detect any additional abnormalities of the prostate or rectum. The patient’s serum PSA was measured to be 6 ng/mL. Image A shows a transabdominal ultrasound of the patient. Which of the following medications should be included to optimally treat the patient's condition?
(A) Clonidine (B) Finasteride (C) Dihydrotestosterone (D) Furosemide
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 71-year-old man complains of urinary hesitancy and nocturia of increasing frequency over the past several months. Digital rectal exam was positive for a slightly enlarged prostate but did not detect any additional abnormalities of the prostate or rectum. The patient’s serum PSA was measured to be 6 ng/mL. Image A shows a transabdominal ultrasound of the patient. Which of the following medications should be included to optimally treat the patient's condition?
options: (A) Clonidine (B) Finasteride (C) Dihydrotestosterone (D) Furosemide
outputs:
The patient has urinary hesitancy and nocturia of increasing frequency over the past several months. The digital rectal exam was positive for a slightly enlarged prostate. The patient's serum PSA was measured to be 6 ng/mL. The patient has benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Clonidine is not a treatment option for BPH. Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor that reduces the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which is a potent stimulator of prostate growth. Dihydrotestosterone is a potent stimulator of prostate growth and would worsen BPH symptoms. Furosemide is a diuretic and would not treat BPH. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and dysarthria. She has a history of hypertension and migraine headaches. She is currently taking lisinopril and topiramate. Her blood pressure is 170/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows Horner's syndrome. There is no evidence of meningism or focal neurological deficits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Migraine headache (B) TIA (C) SAH (D) Hypertensive encephalopathy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and migraine headaches. She presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and dysarthria. She has Horner's syndrome. There is no evidence of meningism or focal neurological deficits. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a TIA (transient ischemic attack). The answer is (B).

Q: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden onset of severe left chest pain. She has no history of cardiac disease or risk factors. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a regular heart rate and rhythm, clear lungs, and no evidence of cardiac failure. An ECG shows a Q wave in leads V2 through V6. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute coronary syndrome (B) Pulmonary embolism (C) Pneumonia (D) Costochondritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe left chest pain. She has no history of cardiac disease or risk factors. An ECG shows a Q wave in leads V2 through V6. This is diagnostic of an ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The patient's symptoms and ECG findings are consistent with acute coronary syndrome. The answer is (A).

Q: A 78-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-month history of worsening confusion, disorientation, and difficulty with memory. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently taking lisinopril and simvastatin. His blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no focal neurological deficits. MRI of the brain shows moderate atrophy of both hemispheres. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Alzheimer disease (B) Multi-infarct dementia (C) Mixed dementia (D) Vascular dementia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 6-month history of worsening confusion, disorientation, and difficulty with memory. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no focal neurological deficits. MRI of the brain shows moderate atrophy of both hemispheres. The patient's symptoms and MRI findings are consistent with Alzheimer disease. The answer is (A).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).
